miscreant.explanation: a person who breaks the law
miscreant.example: "Come back you miscreant!" yelled the woman who just had her purse stolen.

misogynist.explanation: a person who dislikes women in particular
misogynist.example: Many have accused Hemingway of being a quiet misogynist, but recently unearthed letters argue against this belief.

hamper.explanation: prevent the progress or free movement of
hamper.example: As the rain water began to collect in pools on the highway, it began to hamper the flow of traffic.

carping.explanation:
persistently petty and unjustified criticism

or adjective continually complaining about trivial matters; hypercritical
carping.example:
NOUN: The author was very upset about the constant carping of his critics who posted reviews on social media.

ADJECTIVE: Although my mother seemed like a carping critic during my teenage years, her advice turned out to be wise and useful later in life.

magoosh-score-guarantee.explanation: Magoosh guarantees a 5 point increase in your score if you've taken the GRE before.  Learn more at http
magoosh-score-guarantee.example: With Magoosh, Josh was able to increase his GRE score by 7 points and didn't need to take advantage of the Magoosh score guarantee.

dispatch.explanation: the property of being prompt and efficient
dispatch.example: She finished her thesis with dispatch, amazing her advisors who couldn't believe she had written 60 scholarly pages so quickly.

qualm.explanation: uneasiness about the fitness of an action
qualm.example: While he could articulate no clear reason why Harkner's plan would fail, he nevertheless felt qualms about committing any resources to it.

staid.example: Frank came from a staid environment, so he was shocked that his college roommate sold narcotics.

dilapidated.example: The main house has been restored but the gazebo is still dilapidated and unusable.

chivalrous.explanation: being attentive to women like an ideal knight
chivalrous.example: Medieval tales are full of stories of chivalry, in which a young knight must commit deeds of heroism to win the hand of a fair maiden.

deliberate.explanation: think about carefully; weigh the pros and cons of an issue
deliberate.example: Emergency situations such as this call for immediate action and leave no room to deliberate over options.

inkling.explanation: a slight suggestion or vague understanding
inkling.example: Lynne speaks four Romance languages, but she doesn't have an inkling about how East Asian languages are structured.

perquisite.explanation: a right reserved exclusively by a particular person or group (especially a hereditary or official right)
perquisite.example: Even as the dishwasher at the French restaurant, Josh quickly learned that he had the perquisite of being able to eat terrific food for half the price diners would pay.

constraint.example: We don't have many resources, so we'll have to work with some very tight constraints.

malodorous.example: Some thermally active fountains spew sulfur fumes--the air around them is sometimes so malodorous that many have to plug their noses.

compound.explanation: make more intense, stronger, or more marked
compound.example: Her headache was compounded by the construction crew outside, which had six jackhammers going at the same time.

cosmopolitan.explanation: comprising many cultures; global in reach and outlook
cosmopolitan.example: There are few cities in the world as diverse and cosmopolitan as New York.

cumbersome.explanation: difficult to handle or use especially because of size or weight
cumbersome.example: Only ten years ago, being an avid reader and a traveler meant carrying a cumbersome backpack stuffed with books--these days we need only an e-reader.

differentiate.explanation: be a distinctive feature, attribute, or trait (sometimes in positive sense)
differentiate.example: Mozart's long melodic lines differentiate his compositions from other works of late 18th century music.

balk.example: The students were willing to clean up the broken glass, but when the teacher asked them to mop the entire floor, they balked, citing reasons why they needed to leave.

paradoxical.explanation: seemingly contradictory but nonetheless possibly true
paradoxical.example: That light could be both a particle and a wave seems paradoxical, but nonetheless, it is true.

aphorism.explanation: a short instructive saying about a general truth
aphorism.example: Nietzsche was known for using aphorisms, sometimes encapsulating a complex philosophical thought in a mere sentence.

complementary.explanation: enhancing each other's qualities (for two things or more).
complementary.example: The head waiter was careful to tell the amateur diners that red wine was complementary with beef, each bringing out subtle taste notes in the other.

snub.explanation: refuse to acknowledge; reject outright and bluntly
snub.example: Wheeler was completely qualified for the committee, but the board snubbed him, choosing an obviously lesser qualified candidate instead.

resignation.explanation: the acceptance of something unpleasant that can't be avoided
resignation.example: Since Jack could not think of a convincing reason why he had to miss the seminar, he attended it with a sense of resignation.

discreet.explanation: careful to protect one's speech or actions in order to avoid offense or draw attention
discreet.example: The professor thought that he was discreet, subtly wiping the stain off of his shirt, but as soon as he stepped off the podium a heckler in the audience burst out, "You missed a spot".

besiege.explanation: harass, as with questions or requests; cause to feel distressed or worried
besiege.example: After discovering a priceless artifact in her backyard, Jane was besieged by phone calls, emails, and reporters all trying to buy, hold or see the rare piece of history.

stymie.explanation: hinder or prevent the progress or accomplishment of
stymie.example: The engineers found their plans stymied at every turn and were ultimately able to make almost no progress on the project.

obliging.explanation: showing a cheerful willingness to do favors for others
obliging.example: Even after all his success, I found him to be accommodating and obliging, sharing with me his "secret tips" on how to gain wealth and make friends.

futile.explanation: producing no result or effect; unproductive of success
futile.example: I thought I could repair the car myself, but after two days of work with no success, I have to admit that my efforts were futile.

colossal.explanation: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
colossal.example: Few appreciate the colossal scale of the sun: if hollow, it could contain a million Earths.

amply.example: The boat was amply supplied for its year at sea—no man would go hungry or thirsty.

abysmal.example: Coach Ramsey took his newest player off the field after watching a few painful minutes of her abysmal performance.

antiquated.explanation: old-fashioned; belonging to an earlier period in time
antiquated.example: Aunt Betty had antiquated notions about marriage, believing that a man should court a woman for at least a year before receiving a kiss.

vanquish.explanation: come out better in a competition, race, or conflict
vanquish.example: For years, Argentina would dominate in World Cup qualifying matches, only to be vanquished by one of the European countries during the late stages of the tournament.

morph.explanation: To undergo dramatic change in a seamless and barely noticeable fashion.
morph.example: The earnestness of the daytime talk shows of the 1970's has morphed into something far more sensational and vulgar: today guests actually stand up and threaten to take swings at one another.

relegate.example: When Dexter was unable to fulfill his basic duties, instead of firing him, the boss relegated him to kitchen cleanup.

sordid.explanation: involving ignoble actions and motives; arousing moral distaste and contempt; foul and run-down and repulsive
sordid.example: The nightly news simply announced that the senator had had an affair, but the tabloid published all the sordid details of the interaction.

creditable.explanation: deserving of praise but not that amazing
creditable.example: Critics agreed the movie was creditable, but few gave it more than three out of five stars.

laborious.explanation: characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion; especially physical effort
laborious.example: The most laborious job I've had was working 20 hours a day as a fisherman in King Salmon, Alaska.

champion.example: Martin Luther King Jr. championed civil rights fiercely throughout his short life.

debunk.explanation: expose as false ideas and claims, especially while ridiculing
debunk.example: Richard Dawkins tries to debunk religious belief, but his ridicule tends to push people away from his points rather than convince them.

inarticulate.explanation: without or deprived of the use of speech or words
inarticulate.example: Although a brilliant economist, Professor Wilson was completely inarticulate, a terrible lecturer.

boorish.explanation: ill-mannered and coarse or contemptible in behavior or appearance
boorish.example: Bukowski was known for being a boorish drunk and alienating close friends and family.

excruciating.example: After the boulder rolled a couple of feet, pinning my friend's arm, he experienced excruciating pain.

enumerate.explanation: determine the number or amount of
enumerate.example: The survey enumerates the number of happy workers and the number of unhappy workers.

convivial.example: The wedding reception was convivial; friends who hadn't seen each other for ages drank and ate together before heading to the dance floor.

provisional.explanation: under terms not final or fully worked out or agreed upon
provisional.example: Until the corporate office hands down a definitive decision on use of the extra offices, we will share their use in a provisional arrangement.

evasive.explanation: avoiding or escaping from difficulty or danger or commitment
evasive.example: His responses were clearly evasive; he obviously did not want to take on any responsibility or any new work.

decimation.explanation: destroying or killing a large part of the population
decimation.example: The decimation after atomic bombs were dropped on Hiroshima and Nagasaki is incomprehensible.

vie.example: While the other teams in the division actively vie for the championship, this team seems content simply to go through the motions of playing.
